Award.AbstractNarration:
The proton is a particle that is central to our understanding of matter in the universe. It is found in the nucleus of every atom and contributes to the fusion reactions that fuel the stars. Protons are constructed from basic building blocks of matter called quarks, antiquarks (the antimatter counterparts of the quarks) and gluons, but the ways in which these constituents contribute to the properties of the proton are not completely understood. For example, the proton has a property called spin, which is used in medical applications such as MRI scans, but detailed knowledge of how the spins of the quarks and gluons combine to give the spin of the proton is still missing. In this project the investigator will use theoretical models to study the contributions of strange quarks and antiquarks to the properties of the proton and compare the results to experimental measurements from facilities such as the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory and the Jefferson National Accelerator Facility. Undergraduate students will participate in the project, receive training in nuclear and particle physics that is complementary to their undergraduate coursework and gain experience in research methods and scientific communication. The students will present their work at professional meetings and to the broader public.

The goal of this project is to determine the strangeness distributions of the proton and the contribution of strangeness to the proton's electromagnetic properties. Strangeness in the proton refers to its strange and anti-strange quarks, which are created by fluctuations of the proton into meson-baryon states or by quark and gluon interactions. Strangeness distributions describe the share of the proton's momentum that is carried by the strange or anti-strange quarks, which may differ from one another (strangeness asymmetry). Strangeness distributions are important both for our understanding of the structure of the proton, and because they affect the cross sections predicted for dark matter searches. The PI and her students will develop a meson cloud model to represent the fluctuations of the proton into pairs of strange mesons and strange baryons. A statistical model will be used to describe the strange distributions that are created in the mesons and baryons by quark and gluon interactions. Comparison will be made with experimental results for total strangeness and strangeness asymmetry. A light cone model of strangeness wave functions will be used to calculate strangeness electric and magnetic form factors, from which limits on strangeness in the nucleon can be determined from experimental measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proton and other hadrons are constructed of quarks, antiquarks, and gluons, which are building blocks of the Standard Model of particle physics. The primary goal of this project was to understand the properties of the proton in terms of its constituents. Our focus was on how the quark sea, consisting of up, down, and strange quarks, their antiparticles, and gluons, contributes to the momentum of the proton. The constituent contributions to proton momentum are called parton distribution functions (pdfs).

One model for the origin of the sea is the Meson Cloud Model (MCM), which is based on the fluctuation of a proton into a meson-baryon pair, as allowed by the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. The sea quarks then arise from the quarks and antiquarks in the baryon and meson. Another model is the statistical model (SM), which determines the relative probabilities of finding the proton in different allowed states of quarks, antiquarks and gluons. We developed a hybrid model, which included the MCM for the fluctuation and a SM for the pdfs in the baryons and mesons.

Our hybrid model provides a good description of the experimental data for the momentum asymmetry in the up and down antiquark components of the proton sea, for total strangeness, and for strangeness asymmetry (the difference between the strange and anti-strange momentum distributions). We also calculated the spatial extent of the clouds of pions and kaons created by proton fluctuations.

On a fundamental theoretical level, we developed a new formalism for the wave functions that describe the probability that a proton will split into a pion and a nucleon or a Delta particle. This allowed us to make rigorous predictions for the results of the SeaQuest experiment, which measures the momentum distribution of the ratio of down to up antiquarks in the sea. 

Eight undergraduate research assistants from Seattle University (SU) were supported by this grant, with supplemental funding from SU and the Murdock Charitable Trust. The students read original research literature, did analytic calculations, and used computational tools to calculate predictions of our models and compare them to experimental results. They presented their work in posters and talks on campus and at regional and national professional meetings. All of them presented their work in the Conference Experience for Undergraduates at the annual meetings of the Division of Nuclear Physics of the American Physical Society.

Of the four students who have graduated, two are in Ph.D. programs in theoretical nuclear physics, one has completed a Master's degree in physics and is now in industry, and the fourth is planning to apply to graduate school.  The four undergraduates plan to do graduate work in physics or physics education.
